contentrichtext.text: '''Baron Clwyd''', of Abergele in the County of Denbigh, is a title in the [[Peerage of the United Kingdom]]. It was created in 1919 for the [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] politician [[John Roberts, 1st Baron Clwyd|Sir John Roberts, 1st Baronet]], who had previously represented [[Denbighshire West (UK Parliament constituency)|Denbighshire West]] in the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]]. He had already been created a '''Baronet''', of Abergele in the County of Denbigh, in the [[Baronetage of the United Kingdom]] in 1908. Lord Clwyd's father [[John Roberts (Flint MP)|John Roberts]] had earlier been [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Flint (UK Parliament constituency)|Flint]] from 1878 to 1892. {{As of|2010}} the titles are held by the first Baron's great-grandson, the fourth Baron, who succeeded his father in 2006. The title of the barony, Clwyd, is pronounced "Cloo-id". ==Barons Clwyd (1919)== *[[John Roberts, 1st Baron Clwyd|John Herbert Roberts, 1st Baron Clwyd]] (1863–1955) *[[Trevor Roberts, 2nd Baron Clwyd|(John) Trevor Roberts, 2nd Baron Clwyd]] (1900–1987) *(John) Anthony Roberts, 3rd Baron Clwyd (1935–2006) *John Murray Roberts, 4th Baron Clwyd (b. 1971) The [[heir apparent]] is the present holder's son the Hon.
